Title: Crisis on the Margins of the Byzantine Empire: A Bio-Archaeological Project on Resilience and Collapse in Early Christian Development of the Negev Desert

This innovative, data-intensive project explores the contexts of collapse and resilience in the Byzantine early Christian urban centers of the Negev Desert during the 4th-7th century AD. By integrating archaeology, biomolecular analysis, and geological techniques, we will examine the interplay between social disintegration, economic stress, environmental degradation, and the impact of plague on the long-term sustainability of complex societies in resource-limited environments. Our research focuses on the household, landscape, and waste disposal practices of these ancient communities, using a range of methods including artifact analysis, botanical and zoological studies, and chronometric techniques. This project's findings will have critical relevance in today's world, where the expansion of development exacerbates societal vulnerability in marginal regions. While risks include the underdetermined nature of historical and proxy data, the benefits of this research include a critical re-evaluation of current knowledge based on new data, leading to more nuanced and informed generalizations regarding the limits of human ingenuity in sustainable development. Ultimately, this project will provide valuable insights into the sustainability of complex societies in challenging environments, informing strategies for building resilience in the face of adversity.
